title: How to get past the stigma of going into a career in education - Quora

response.answer_text: As I write this…my thoughts turn to my time in school…early years…then all through the remaining time. The teachers that I had in grade school remain in my memory the clearest. They spend more time with us…we saw them every school day. Later on, when we changed classes and rooms and teachers…our relationship with them was not a familiar or intense. Everyone reading this…everyone, will now think back and remember their school days and all will remember one or more of their teachers. They will remember those teachers that were kind…were caring…were pretty, or handsome, were stern and strict, who we brought flowers to, and book reports and who we wanted to please and make them proud of us…who we were afraid of. My point is, of course, that no matter how old we become, the teachers that we spent so much of our lives with, had a tremendous impact on our lives. They, outside of our family members, were the most important people that we saw and interacted with. They helped make us the people we are today. I worked with hundreds of children over the years. Many had been beaten, starved of food, kindness, love or raped or beaten or ignored, belittled,…all those things that twisted and cruel people do to children…because they can. And, one of the few things in each of those children’s lives that still mattered to them was to go to school. School was one of the few constants in their lives…their place of refuge…no brutal parent lurking there…no fear of sexual assault or being bitten, burned or beaten…they were safe…they, for a while, were normal…they belonged. Sometimes…that was the only place…they felt safe. So….”stigma” of being a teacher? The “stigma” is and should be…a statement of pride…a statement of worth…a statement of meaning and fulfillment…teachers shape and guid young minds and young ideals…The greatest statement any of us can make…about what we did in life is “I was a teacher.” Go…teach…become a golden memory to thousands of children.
